description.en: The University Galleries presents:  Won Ju Lim: Castings Los Angeles-based artist Won Ju Lim investigates liminal spaces through sculpture, installation, light and shadow. Incorporating layered references to early 20th century architecture, literature, and film, Lim’s multi-faceted installations consider the role of memory in our experience of built environments.  Castings  presents a 15-year survey of the artist's work and features a new large-scale installation comprised of over 200 architectural models and objects. Lim will also premiere her new film similarly titled  Casting , inspired by Celeste Albaret’s recounting of writer Marcel Proust’s final years. Artist Talk: Thursday, September 21, 5-6PM Orchard Suite, The Union, 2nd Floor Exhibition Reception: Thursday, September 21, 6-8PM University Library Gallery
description.es: Las Galerías de la Universidad presenta: Won Ju Lim: Castings con sede en Los Ángeles, Won Ju Lim investiga los espacios liminales a través de esculturas, instalación, luz y sombra.

The tea room and garden provide a unique and essential way for students and community members to study Japanese aesthetics and traditional arts, built particularly around the time-honored art form of  Chado , the Way of Tea. The Sokiku Nakatani Tea Room and Garden provides direct experiential knowledge of Japanese culture through participatory educational experiences and promotes multicultural and interdisciplinary perspectives through programming designed to increase cultural understanding and to be a space where all may experience peace and tranquility in an experiential environment. description.en: The Wellness, Safety and Sexual Assault Committee shall be an advisory board to the Vice President of University Affairs. It will assist in better understanding issues and support of services in the topics pertaining to student safety, wellness and sexual assault. Topics may include basic needs initiatives, mental health resources, campus safety, sexual assault prevention and raising awareness of resources that serve students dealing with any of the issues that ascertain to these subjects. The committee will also serve as a point of contact for University-wide conversations via the Sacramento State Campus Wellness Steering Group regarding students’ perspectives on wellness and safety. The committee will also work to ensure that the services and resources on campus regarding these topics are provided and available to all students, and work with relevant campus partners to ensure it.

title.en: AI Workshop 3: Constructing Strategies for Engaging AI in Your Course
title.es: Taller de IA 3: Construcción de estrategias para involucrar a AI en su curso

date.es: Martes, 28 de noviembre de 2023, 11:30 am - 1pm PST

description.en: The Center for Teaching and Learning (CTL) continues its journey into the world of generative artificial intelligence (AI) with this second workshop series exploring the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on education today.  We invite faculty and staff to strategize and redefine the possible through collaboration in the CTL’s Hornet Hub of AI explorers. Where you and your fellow Hornet Hub of AI explorers share your innovative and proactive plans for responsibly leveraging generative artificial intelligence to enhance human intelligence, purpose, and potential at Sac State – where we redefine the possible. If you missed the first two workshops you can still join us to brainstorm with your colleagues on ways you want to explore using AI and provide feedback on their proposed plans for engaging with AI.     Faculty colleagues are working on assignments in their course that may be suitable for engagement with or adapting to using AI.    Staff may want to explore using AI to improve productivity in meetings, projects, communications, and more!      For questions about accessibility or to request reasonable accommodations, please contact Som Sayasone at  ctl@csus.edu  at least five (5) business days in advance or as soon as possible. You can also complete our  CTL Event Accommodation Request Form .
description.es: El Centro para la Enseñanza y el Aprendizaje (CTL) continúa su viaje al mundo de la inteligencia artificial generativa (IA) con esta segunda serie de taller que explora el impacto de la inteligencia artificial (IA) en la educación actual.

title.en: Learning with a Leader - Emily Tupper
title.es: Aprendiendo con un líder - Emily Tupper

date.es: Viernes 1 de diciembre de 2023, 9 a 10am PST

description.en: Join us as we spend time getting to know some of our key campus leaders in the Learning with a Leader program.  Learning & Development will host this month's leader in a live, fireside chat style discussion about their journey to leadership, with a specific focus on their unique leadership qualities and the role that ongoing learning and professional development has played in their journey.  These forums are a safe space for our employees to listen as each leader shares their story, and participants will have the option to ask questions during the forum. Leader:  Emily Tupper, LCSW, Director of Campus Wellness and CARES Bio:   Emily Tupper (she/her/ella) is a Licensed Clinical Social Worker who joined Sac State to serve as the Director of Campus Wellness, Crisis Assistance & Resource Education Support (CARES) and Basic Needs in Fall 2022. Emily has a Bachelor’s Degree in Psychology and Spanish Language Studies from UC Davis. Emily is proudly Sac State made having completed her Master of Social Work in 2006. Prior to joining the University Emily worked for Sutter Health for 16 years, in the greater Sacramento region, as both a direct practice Clinician, and then as the Community Services Manager for the Sutter SeniorCare Program of All Inclusive Care for the Elderly (PACE) population health Plan. During her career with Sutter Health Emily was a part of multiple special projects and continuously sought to improve the patient experience. Being a disabled woman, Emily is passionate about social justice and has focused her career on working with marginalized and underserved populations to promote health equity by addressing systemic problems through process improvement initiatives. Emily has a human centered leadership style prioritizing the well-being, growth and empowerment of team members. Emily is recognized for her ability to foster open communication, innovate and develop strategic partnerships to achieve organizational goals and create opportunities for everyone to thrive and contribute their best. In her current role, Emily looks forward to working with collaborators and stakeholders, on and off campus, to achieve the wellness imperatives of the University’s 2023-2028 Strategic Plan and to ensure that the basic needs of our student body are being met. In her free time, Emily enjoys creating mosaic art, working in the garden with her spouse and sharing a home cooked meal with friends at their regular game nights. Note:  Please check in advance with your supervisor before registering to ensure their support and that attendance does not conflict with operational needs. Planned accommodations:  Automatic captioning - All Learning & Development workshops/training sessions are held via Zoom and will utilize the built-in AI for the purposes of automatic captioning.  If you require further reasonable accommodations to participate in this event, please notify Learning and Development at  learn-dev@csus.edu  no later than five (5) business days in advance of this event.
description.es: Únase a nosotros a medida que pasamos tiempo conociendo a algunos de nuestros líderes clave del campus en el programa de aprendizaje con un líder de líderes.

description.en: The Wellness in the Classroom project is hosting a monthly employee lunchtime self-care series. The next session is on Friday, December 1, from noon to 12:50pm. The topic is gratitude and it will be presented by Dr. Lani Gleason from the Department of Biological Sciences. Gratitude is the emotion experienced when we are thankful for positive aspects of our lives. In this session, Dr. Gleason will first discuss the many benefits of gratitude, including a reduction in stress and anxiety. Dr. Gleason will then provide some resources, tools, and apps that you can use to start building your own personal gratitude practice.

description.en: This class is geared to serve the beginner and average rider. Curriculum includes routine maintenance, cleaning, flat repairs, brake and gear adjustments, trail repairs, and ergonomics. Special attention is given to the basics of user maintenance and simple repairs with minimal tools. You will walk away with a tune up on your bike and the knowledge to go with it. You will become a better rider by understanding your bicycle's needs and capabilities. Bring your own bike so we can advise you on its specific needs. Space is limited to four people for individual attention. Total instruction time is six hours, with a break for lunch. Minimum age is 18 or current Sac State student.  Activity level 1. Sac State Student: $50 Affiliate: $75 Public: $95 Is cost a barrier? Check out our  NEW Bike Class Scholarship  to attend this class for $12.50! Register Now! keyword: bikeclinic

description.en: Facilitator:  Juliana Goodlaw-Morris Course Description:  The holidays are a time of family, friends, laughter and... waste!  In fact, approximately 25% more trash is created during the holidays than any other time of the year.  This session will guide participants to think about how to continue living sustainably, even during the holiday season.  Participants will leave the session with strategies that are easily implemented all year round to reduce their impact on the planet and save money.  Come with an open mind, and be willing to share and learn not only from the presenter but each other as well. Register in CSU Learn:  coming soon!

description.en: Finals are approaching, but don't worry, Hornets - you got this! Don't forget to take breaks to relax and let your brain rest - SAA can help! Join us for the SAA Study Break, we'll have coffee, therapy dogs, snacks, relaxing activities, and more to help you feel calm, collected, and re-energized for the last few weeks of school. If you just want a change of scenery while you study, bring your headphones and come snag a table away from the hubbub and enjoy some free coffee while you work. Whatever you do, don't think you're in this alone! We'll have a variety of types of creamer and coffee alternatives.

description.en: Give back, clean up, make friends, and have fun! Every month, Peak Adventures hosts a river cleanup where volunteers hike along the American River Parkway picking up litter, debris, and removing invasive plant species from the trail’s pathways. This cleanup effort creates a much more enjoyable experience for parkway visitors, protects our river ecosystems, and improves water quality for the community. So come out and clean-up! The minimum age is 18 or current Sac State student.  Activity level 1.  Volunteer and Leadership Initiative credits available, please inquire day of the event. Gloves, garbage bags, trash grabbers, and hand sanitizer provided. No pre-registration is necessary. Meet at the Guy West Bridge.

description.en: Information session: Communication Studies Graduate Program In national surveys, employers consistently rank communication as one of their top sought-after skills for job candidates, especially the ability to analyze and communicate complex information, and successfully navigate interpersonal relationships at work. The Communication Studies Department invites staff, faculty, and students to an information session about our master’s program, where students can specialize in the theory and practice of various areas of communication including: intercultural, interpersonal, instructional, media, organizational, political, rhetorical, and health communication. An undergraduate degree in Communication Studies is not required. Join us at 4:30 p.m. Wednesday, Dec. 6, in Mendocino Hall, room 3009, or via Zoom (ID: 817 3566 5275). Questions? Please email Graduate Program Coordinator Dr. Shawna Malvini Redden.
description.es: Sesión de información: Programa de posgrado de estudios de comunicación en encuestas nacionales, los empleadores clasifican constantemente la comunicación como una de sus principales habilidades solicitadas para candidatos de trabajo, especialmente la capacidad de analizar y comunicar información compleja, y navegar con éxito en las relaciones interpersonales en el trabajo.

description.en: In the Lead Clinic, students will learn the fundamentals of lead climbing and belaying. Staff will instruct and allow you to practice for the assessment during this clinic. Students will work through clipping, falling, catching falls and everything in between. If you are new to leading, taking multiple clinics is encouraged to build up your practice. Shoes, harness, belay device, rope and helmet are provided. Pre-registration is required. Cost is $5 per person.  Must be top rope certified at The WELL .

description.en: Facilitator:  Debbie Marcusson, CSU Chancellor's Office Course Description:   Research has shown that happiness and positivity lead to success. During this workshop we will answer the question of “what fuels success?” If we work hard, become successful then we will be happy; however, the formula is backwards. If we choose happiness, the brain works better, and we become successful.  Join this engaging and interactive learning experience on how positive psychology can lead to personal and professional success. We will explore the happiness advantage principles that can help shift our mindset through positive psychology. Registration link in CSU Learn coming soon!

title.en: Symposium on Transitional Housing Communities: Strategies for Recovery from Homelessness
title.es: Simposio sobre comunidades de vivienda de transición: estrategias para la recuperación de las personas sin hogar

date.es: Martes, 12 de diciembre de 2023, 9am a 3pm PST

description.en: Please join us for a one-day interactive symposium at Sacramento State dedicated to exploring innovative ways of designing safe and supportive transitional spaces (e.g., interim housing communities) for individuals experiencing homelessness in Sacramento County. The symposium will feature faculty and student research as well as professionals working to support our unhoused neighbors. We hope you will commit to engaging with us on this topic for the full-day of presentations and collaborative discussion. Attendees will learn about a new set of tools, ideas (e.g., trauma-informed design), and proposals for local transitional housing communities as well as have the opportunity to create new partnerships in advancing solutions to this challenging issue. This event is sponsored by Sacramento State’s Department of Design (College of Arts & Letters) and the  Center for Health Practice, Policy, and Research (College of Health & Human Services). Professionals who attend the entire symposium will be eligible for up to 5 LU's from the American Institute of Architects.
description.es: Únase a nosotros para un simposio interactivo de un día en el estado de Sacramento dedicado a explorar formas innovadoras de diseñar espacios de transición seguros y de apoyo (por ejemplo, comunidades de vivienda provisional) para personas que experimentan personas sin hogar en el condado de Sacramento.

title.en: Doctorate in Educational Leadership | Info Session (online)

date.es: Miércoles 13 de diciembre de 2023, 12 - 1pm PST

description.en: Ready to transform your leadership?   Find out how a Doctorate in Educational Leadership might be the right fit for you in this one-hour information session. Information Sessions include a 30–40 minute program overview—co-facilitated by Associate Director, Dr. Rose Borunda, and Interim Faculty Director, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan. There will also be a question and answer session, approximately 20–30 minutes in length. Two-hour, in-person sessions will include an optional class visit. If you require any accommodations, please notify us at least 72-hours in advance.  edd@csus.edu  |  www.csus.edu… Online meeting links will be sent to all registered participants approximately 2 days prior to the event. Champion Change: Become a Leader in Education Advance your career in Education and learn the skills necessary to become an equity warrior in Educational Leadership and Public Policy. Without you, change doesn't happen. If you're ready to make a difference as a school district superintendent, school principal, community college administrator, governmental analyst, community outreach program administrator, or other educational leader—the Sacramento State Educational Doctorate (Ed.D.) program can advance you on your path. The Sacramento State Ed.D. program takes advantage of its location in California's capital by calling upon a network of education policymakers, analysts, and executive leaders from the region’s K-12 districts and the community colleges. You will have access to a faculty that includes former administrators and world-renowned researchers. What makes our program unique?   Face-to-face* interaction with students and faculty 	 Every-other-weekend classes	 Renowned faculty who want you to succeed	 Supportive cohort-based learning The program is designed for working professionals like you—it focuses on in-person classes conducted on the weekends. During the program, you will learn to lead educational environments that promote learning, equity, and achievement for all students. Advance your career Less than 2 percent of the U.S. population has a doctorate, and that rarity puts you in a desirable and very employable category. With a doctorate, U.S. Census reports indicate, you may earn as much as $500,000 more over the course of your career than with a master’s degree alone. In fact, in California K-16 education administrators earned well over $100,000 a year in the first quarter of 2015. Are you cut out to be an Ed.D.? To find out if you have what it takes to be a Doctor of Education – a transformational leader who can make change happen in your organization – join us at an information session. Use the REGISTER button to rsvp for an information session. In the meantime, we invite you to explore our  website  to learn more about our executive-style program designed for working professionals. Classes are held every other weekend, year-round so that you can earn your degree in about 34 months. Please call our office at 916-278-2282 if you have any questions, or email us at  edd@csus.edu . We look forward to getting to know you better.

description.es: Las reuniones de Alcohólicos Anónimos (AA) se ofrecerán en la sala Canyon de la Unión Universitaria (tercer piso) desde el mediodía de 1 p.m.
